nodes.text: Conventional ex-ante cost-benefit analysis presumes cost and benefit estimates are sufficiently accurate and unbiased to guide effective public resource allocation; we test whether this presumption holds
Dataset and scope: sample of 2,062 public investment projects across eight types (bridges, buildings, BRT, dams, power plants, rail, roads, tunnels), 104 countries, 1927-2013

Measurement protocol: cost accuracy measured by cost overrun = actual cost divided by estimated cost; benefit accuracy measured by benefit overrun = actual benefit divided by estimated benefit; proxying costs by construction capital costs and benefits by first-year benefits

Result: cost estimates are systematically biased toward underestimation, with average cost overruns >1 for all investment types and fat right tails (e.g., roads average 1.24, dams 1.96; overall weighted average ~1.39/1.43)

Result: benefit estimates are systematically biased toward overestimation for several types (notably BRT and rail: average benefit overruns 0.42 and 0.66 respectively; overall weighted average ~0.94/0.83), with skewed left tails

Result and implication: cost underestimation and benefit overestimation compound rather than cancel, causing routine overestimation of ex-ante benefit-cost ratios by roughly 50 to 200 percent and producing systematic resource misallocation

Evidence: statistical tests reject unbiasedness with overwhelming significance (Wilcoxon p<0.0001 for costs and benefits pooled; D Agostino skewness and Anscombe-Glynn kurtosis tests show extreme skewness and fat tails; Mann-Whitney tests reject balance of cost and benefit errors)
Evidence: Table 1 specifics showing per-type averages and sample sizes (examples: dams N=243 cost overrun 1.96; rail N=264 cost overrun 1.40, benefit overrun 0.66; roads N=869 cost overrun 1.24)
Claim: results are robust to alternative statistical approaches and subsampling, including Bayesian modeling and analyses on the subsample of 327 projects with both cost and benefit data

Claim (explanation): behavioral mechanisms—optimism bias, overconfidence, the planning fallacy, probability neglect, and strategic misrepresentation—are primary root causes of systematic cost underestimation and benefit overestimation

Claim: frequently cited proximate causes (delays, geology, complexity, scope changes, price inflation) act as intermediate manifestations of the underlying behavioral biases rather than as fundamental root causes

Conclusion: conventional ex-ante cost-benefit analysis is systematically misleading in public investments (the 'cost-benefit fallacy') and thus can produce worse-than-useless guidance leading to misallocated resources

Methodological robustness: statistical tests were run on full sample (N=2,062) and on subsample with paired cost and benefit data (N=327); Bayesian MCMC (JAGS via rjags) used to test influence of type, geography, and time

Limitation: data availability constraints and selection/survival biases likely make sample conservative (data availability correlates with better-managed projects; many poorly performing projects lack released data); benefits data smaller and noisier than cost data

Recommendation: four reforms to correct the cost-benefit fallacy — (1) systematic, empirical de-biasing using reference class forecasting and outside view; (2) skin-in-the-game incentives for forecasters; (3) independent, politically insulated audits and transparency; (4) adapt CBA practice to democratic, non-technocratic decision processes
